an4.48:4.1: At one time the Buddha was staying near Sāvatthī, in Jeta’s Grove, Anāthapiṇḍika’s monastery.
an4.48:4.2: Now at that time Venerable Visākha, Pañcāli’s son, was educating, encouraging, firing up, and inspiring the mendicants in the assembly hall with a Dharma talk. His words were polished, clear, articulate, expressing the meaning, comprehensive, and independent.
an4.48:4.3: Then in the late afternoon, the Buddha came out of solitude and went to the assembly hall.
an4.48:4.4: He sat down on the indicated seat,
an4.48:5.1: “Mendicants, who was educating, encouraging, firing up, and inspiring the mendicants in the assembly hall with a Dharma talk?”
an4.48:5.2: “Sir, it was Venerable Visākha, Pañcāli’s son.”
an4.48:6.1: Then the Buddha said to Visākha:
an4.48:6.3: It’s good that you educate, encourage, fire up, and inspire the mendicants in the assembly hall with a Dharma talk, with words that are polished, clear, articulate, expressing the meaning, comprehensive, and independent.”
an4.48:7.1: “Though an astute person is mixed up with fools,
an4.48:7.2: they don’t know unless he speaks.
an4.48:7.3: But when he speaks they know,
an4.48:8.1: He should speak and illustrate the teaching,
an4.48:8.2: holding up the banner of the seers.
an4.48:8.3: Words well spoken are the seers’ banner,
an4.48:8.4: for the teaching is the banner of the seers.”
